sn3.4:1.2: Sitting to one side, King Pasenadi of Kosala said to the Blessed One:
sn3.4:1.3: “Here, venerable sir, while I was alone in seclusion, a reflection arose in my mind thus:
sn3.4:1.4: ‘Who now treat themselves as dear, and who treat themselves as a foe?’
sn3.4:1.5: Then, venerable sir, it occurred to me:
sn3.4:1.6: ‘Those who engage in misconduct of body, speech, and mind
sn3.4:1.9: “We regard ourselves as dear, ” still they treat themselves as a foe.
sn3.4:1.11: Because of their own accord they act towards themselves in the same way that a foe might act towards a foe;
sn3.4:1.12: therefore they treat themselves as a foe.
sn3.4:1.13: But those who engage in good conduct of body, speech, and mind
sn3.4:1.16: “We regard ourselves as a foe, ” still they treat themselves as dear.
sn3.4:1.18: Because of their own accord they act towards themselves in the same way that a dear person might act towards one who is dear;
sn3.4:1.19: therefore they treat themselves as dear. ’”
sn3.4:2.1: “So it is, great king! So it is, great king!”
sn3.4:3.2: One should not yoke oneself to evil,
sn3.4:3.3: For happiness is not easily gained
sn3.4:3.4: By one who does a wrongful deed.
sn3.4:4.1: “When one is seized by the End-maker
sn3.4:4.2: As one discards the human state,
sn3.4:4.3: What can one call truly one’s own?
sn3.4:4.4: What does one take when one goes?
sn3.4:4.6: Like a shadow that never departs?
sn3.4:5.2: That a mortal does right here:
sn3.4:5.3: This is what is truly one’s own,
sn3.4:5.4: This one takes when one goes;
sn3.4:5.5: This is what follows one along
sn3.4:5.6: Like a shadow that never departs.
sn3.4:6.1: “Therefore one should do what is good
sn3.4:6.2: As a collection for the future life.
sn3.4:6.3: Merits are the support for living beings
sn3.4:6.4: [When they arise] in the other world. ”
